abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Pollution Abatement Project
            for Egypt received a satisfactory outcome rating with
            moderate risk to development outcome. The Bank received a
            moderately satisfactory outcome rating while the Borrower
            received a satisfactory outcome rating. The Project was
            restructured twice. The first restructuring was a level 2
            restructuring to extend the closing date by 18 months due to
            the delays caused by the global financial crisis and due to
            the political events in Egypt. The second restructuring was
            also a level 2 restructuring to (a) extend the closing date
            by another 12 months to properly complete project
            activities, and (b) revise two intermediate performance
            indicators to take into account that the CDM projects did
            not move forward in a timely manner. There were several
            lessons learned from this project and are as follows: (1) as
            the Bank becomes increasingly involved with private sector
            entities, there is a need to improve the capacity of the
            Bank to handle common commercial procurement practices, (2)
            the value added of issuing loans in local currency should be
            considered at the preparation stage, (3) use of concessional
            finance has proved effective in triggering private
            investments in pollution abatement and the approach should
            be scaled-up and replicated in other countries, (4) internal
            rates of return (IRR) evaluation for pollution abatement
            investments could be used in the future to develop a
            differential scheme, (5) installation of continuous
            monitoring systems should form an integral part of grant
            funded sub-projects, (6) carbon finance-linked projects
            require careful preparation with contractual commitments upfront.
